description: [Status: stable] [Name: implicit-namespace-package] [Message: File {filename} is part of an implicit namespace package. Add an __init__.py.] What it does Checks for packages that are missing an __init__.py file. Why is this bad? Python packages are directories that contain a file named __init__.py. The existence of this file indicates that the directory is a Python package, and so it can be imported the same way a module can be imported. Directories that lack an __init__.py file can still be imported, but they're indicative of a special kind of package, known as a "namespace package" (see: PEP 420). Namespace packages are less widely used, so a package that lacks an __init__.py file is typically meant to be a regular package, and the absence of the __init__.py file is probably an oversight.

namespace-packages.option_description:
Mark the specified directories as namespace packages. For the purpose of
module resolution, Ruff will treat those directories and all their subdirectories
as if they contained an __init__.py file.



Example usage:

pyproject.tomlruff.toml


[tool.ruff]
namespace-packages = ["airflow/providers"]



namespace-packages = ["airflow/providers"]
